text: XXVIII
text_tokenized: XXVIII

text: Her uncle and both her aunts were in the drawing - room when Fanny went down .
text_tokenized: Her uncle and both her aunts were in the drawing - room when Fanny went down .

text: To the former she was an interesting object , and he saw with pleasure the general elegance of her appearance , and her being in remarkably good looks .
text_tokenized: To the former she was an interesting object , and he saw with pleasure the general elegance of her appearance , and her being in remarkably good looks .

text: The neatness and propriety of her dress was all that he would allow himself to commend in her presence , but upon her leaving the room again soon afterwards , he spoke of her beauty with very decided praise .
text_tokenized: The neatness and propriety of her dress was all that he would allow himself to commend in her presence , but upon her leaving the room again soon afterwards , he spoke of her beauty with very decided praise .

text: “ Yes , ” said Lady Bertram , “ she looks very well .
text_tokenized: “ Yes , ” said Lady Bertram , “ she looks very well .

text: I sent Chapman to her . ”
text_tokenized: I sent Chapman to her . ”

text: “ Look well !
text_tokenized: “ Look well !

text: Oh , yes ! ” cried Mrs. Norris , “ she has good reason to look well with all her advantages : brought up in this family as she has been , with all the benefit of her cousins ’ manners before her .
text_tokenized: Oh , yes ! ” cried Mrs. Norris , “ she has good reason to look well with all her advantages : brought up in this family as she has been , with all the benefit of her cousins ’ manners before her .

text: Only
text_tokenized: Only

text: think , my dear Sir Thomas , what extraordinary advantages you and I have been the means of giving her .
text_tokenized: think , my dear Sir Thomas , what extraordinary advantages you and I have been the means of giving her .

text: The very gown you have been taking notice of is your own generous present to her when dear Mrs. Rushworth married .
text_tokenized: The very gown you have been taking notice of is your own generous present to her when dear Mrs. Rushworth married .

text: What would she have been if we had not taken her by the hand ?
text_tokenized: What would she have been if we had not taken her by the hand ?

text: Sir Thomas said no more ; but when they sat down to table the eyes of the two young men assured him that the subject might be gently touched again , when the ladies withdrew , with more success .
text_tokenized: Sir Thomas said no more ; but when they sat down to table the eyes of the two young men assured him that the subject might be gently touched again , when the ladies withdrew , with more success .

text: Fanny saw that she was approved ; and the consciousness of looking well made her look still better .
text_tokenized: Fanny saw that she was approved ; and the consciousness of looking well made her look still better .

text: From a variety of causes she was happy , and she was soon made still happier ; for
text_tokenized: From a variety of causes she was happy , and she was soon made still happier ; for

text: in following her aunts out of the room , Edmund , who was holding open the door , said , as she passed him , “ You must dance with me , Fanny ; you must keep two dances for me ; any two that you like , except the first . ”
text_tokenized: in following her aunts out of the room , Edmund , who was holding open the door , said , as she passed him , “ You must dance with me , Fanny ; you must keep two dances for me ; any two that you like , except the first . ”

text: She had nothing more to wish for .
text_tokenized: She had nothing more to wish for .

text: She had hardly ever been in a state so nearly approaching high spirits in her life .
text_tokenized: She had hardly ever been in a state so nearly approaching high spirits in her life .

text: Her cousins ’ former gaiety on the day of a ball was no longer surprising to her ; she felt it to be indeed very charming , and was actually practising her steps about the drawing - room as long as she could be safe from the notice of her aunt Norris , who was entirely taken up at first in fresh arranging and injuring the noble fire which the butler had prepared .
text_tokenized: Her cousins ’ former gaiety on the day of a ball was no longer surprising to her ; she felt it to be indeed very charming , and was actually practising her steps about the drawing - room as long as she could be safe from the notice of her aunt Norris , who was entirely taken up at first in fresh arranging and injuring the noble fire which the butler had prepared .

text: Half an hour followed that would have been at least languid under any other circumstances , but Fanny ’s happiness still prevailed .
text_tokenized: Half an hour followed that would have been at least languid under any other circumstances , but Fanny ’s happiness still prevailed .

text: It was but to think of her conversation with Edmund , and what was the restlessness of Mrs. Norris ?
text_tokenized: It was but to think of her conversation with Edmund , and what was the restlessness of Mrs. Norris ?

text: What were the yawns of Lady Bertram ?
text_tokenized: What were the yawns of Lady Bertram ?

text: The gentlemen joined them ; and soon after began the sweet expectation of a carriage , when a general spirit of ease and enjoyment seemed diffused , and they all stood about and talked and laughed , and every moment had its pleasure and its hope .
text_tokenized: The gentlemen joined them ; and soon after began the sweet expectation of a carriage , when a general spirit of ease and enjoyment seemed diffused , and they all stood about and talked and laughed , and every moment had its pleasure and its hope .

text: Fanny felt that there must be a struggle in Edmund ’s cheerfulness , but it was delightful to see the effort so successfully made .
text_tokenized: Fanny felt that there must be a struggle in Edmund ’s cheerfulness , but it was delightful to see the effort so successfully made .

text: When the carriages were really heard , when the guests began really to assemble , her own gaiety of heart was much subdued : the sight of so many strangers threw her back into herself ; and besides the gravity and formality of the first great circle , which the manners of neither Sir Thomas nor Lady Bertram were of a kind to do away , she found herself occasionally called on to endure something worse .
text_tokenized: When the carriages were really heard , when the guests began really to assemble , her own gaiety of heart was much subdued : the sight of so many strangers threw her back into herself ; and besides the gravity and formality of the first great circle , which the manners of neither Sir Thomas nor Lady Bertram were of a kind to do away , she found herself occasionally called on to endure something worse .

text: She was introduced here and there by her uncle , and forced to be spoken to , and to curtsey , and speak again .
text_tokenized: She was introduced here and there by her uncle , and forced to be spoken to , and to curtsey , and speak again .

text: This was a hard duty , and she was never summoned to it without looking at William , as he walked about at his ease in the background of the scene , and longing to be with him .
text_tokenized: This was a hard duty , and she was never summoned to it without looking at William , as he walked about at his ease in the background of the scene , and longing to be with him .

text: The entrance of the Grants and Crawfords was a favourable epoch .
text_tokenized: The entrance of the Grants and Crawfords was a favourable epoch .

text: The stiffness of the meeting soon gave way before their popular manners and more diffused intimacies : little groups were formed , and everybody grew comfortable .
text_tokenized: The stiffness of the meeting soon gave way before their popular manners and more diffused intimacies : little groups were formed , and everybody grew comfortable .

text: Fanny felt the advantage ; and , drawing back from the toils of civility , would have been again most happy , could she have kept her eyes from wandering between Edmund and Mary Crawford .
text_tokenized: Fanny felt the advantage ; and , drawing back from the toils of civility , would have been again most happy , could she have kept her eyes from wandering between Edmund and Mary Crawford .

text: _ She _ looked all loveliness — and what might not be the end of it ?
text_tokenized: _ She _ looked all loveliness — and what might not be the end of it ?

text: Her own musings were
text_tokenized: Her own musings were

text: brought to an end on perceiving Mr. Crawford before her , and her thoughts were put into another channel by his engaging her almost instantly for the first two dances .
text_tokenized: brought to an end on perceiving Mr. Crawford before her , and her thoughts were put into another channel by his engaging her almost instantly for the first two dances .

text: Her happiness on this occasion was very much _ à la mortal _ , finely chequered .
text_tokenized: Her happiness on this occasion was very much _ à la mortal _ , finely chequered .

text: To be secure of a partner at first was a most essential good — for the moment of beginning was now growing seriously near ; and she so little understood her own claims as to think that if Mr. Crawford had not asked her , she must have been the last to be sought after , and should have received a partner only through a series of inquiry , and bustle , and interference , which would have been terrible ; but at the same time there was a pointedness in his manner of asking her which she did not like , and she saw his eye glancing for a moment at her necklace , with a smile — she thought there was a smile — which made her blush and feel wretched .
text_tokenized: To be secure of a partner at first was a most essential good — for the moment of beginning was now growing seriously near ; and she so little understood her own claims as to think that if Mr. Crawford had not asked her , she must have been the last to be sought after , and should have received a partner only through a series of inquiry , and bustle , and interference , which would have been terrible ; but at the same time there was a pointedness in his manner of asking her which she did not like , and she saw his eye glancing for a moment at her necklace , with a smile — she thought there was a smile — which made her blush and feel wretched .

text: And though there was no second glance to disturb her , though his object seemed then to be only quietly agreeable , she could not get the better of her embarrassment , heightened as it was by the idea of his perceiving it , and had no composure till he turned away to some one else .
text_tokenized: And though there was no second glance to disturb her , though his object seemed then to be only quietly agreeable , she could not get the better of her embarrassment , heightened as it was by the idea of his perceiving it , and had no composure till he turned away to some one else .

text: Then she could gradually rise up to the genuine satisfaction of having a partner , a voluntary partner , secured against the dancing began . When the company were moving into the ballroom , she found herself for the first time near Miss Crawford , whose eyes and smiles were immediately and more unequivocally directed as her brother ’s had been , and who was beginning to speak on the subject , when Fanny , anxious to get the story over , hastened to give the explanation of the second necklace : the real chain .
text_tokenized: Then she could gradually rise up to the genuine satisfaction of having a partner , a voluntary partner , secured against the dancing began . When the company were moving into the ballroom , she found herself for the first time near Miss Crawford , whose eyes and smiles were immediately and more unequivocally directed as her brother ’s had been , and who was beginning to speak on the subject , when Fanny , anxious to get the story over , hastened to give the explanation of the second necklace : the real chain .

text: Miss Crawford listened ; and all her intended compliments and insinuations to Fanny were forgotten : she felt only one thing ; and her eyes , bright as they had been before , shewing they could yet be brighter , she exclaimed with eager pleasure , “ Did he ?
text_tokenized: Miss Crawford listened ; and all her intended compliments and insinuations to Fanny were forgotten : she felt only one thing ; and her eyes , bright as they had been before , shewing they could yet be brighter , she exclaimed with eager pleasure , “ Did he ?

text: Did Edmund ?
text_tokenized: Did Edmund ?

text: That was like himself .
text_tokenized: That was like himself .

text: No other man would have thought of it .
text_tokenized: No other man would have thought of it .

text: I honour him beyond expression . ”
text_tokenized: I honour him beyond expression . ”

text: And she looked around as if longing to tell him so .
text_tokenized: And she looked around as if longing to tell him so .

text: He was not near , he was attending a party of ladies out of the room ; and Mrs. Grant coming up to the two girls , and taking an arm of each , they followed with the rest .
text_tokenized: He was not near , he was attending a party of ladies out of the room ; and Mrs. Grant coming up to the two girls , and taking an arm of each , they followed with the rest .

text: Fanny ’s heart sunk , but there was no leisure for thinking long even of Miss Crawford ’s feelings .
text_tokenized: Fanny ’s heart sunk , but there was no leisure for thinking long even of Miss Crawford ’s feelings .

text: They were in the ballroom , the violins were playing , and her mind was in a flutter that forbade its fixing on anything serious .
text_tokenized: They were in the ballroom , the violins were playing , and her mind was in a flutter that forbade its fixing on anything serious .

text: She must watch the general arrangements , and see how everything was done .
text_tokenized: She must watch the general arrangements , and see how everything was done .

text: In a few minutes Sir Thomas came to her , and asked if she were engaged ; and the “ Yes , sir ; to Mr. Crawford , ” was exactly what he had intended to hear .
text_tokenized: In a few minutes Sir Thomas came to her , and asked if she were engaged ; and the “ Yes , sir ; to Mr. Crawford , ” was exactly what he had intended to hear .

text: Mr. Crawford was not far off ; Sir Thomas brought him to her , saying something which discovered to Fanny , that _ she _ was to lead the way and open the ball ; an idea that had never occurred to her before .
text_tokenized: Mr. Crawford was not far off ; Sir Thomas brought him to her , saying something which discovered to Fanny , that _ she _ was to lead the way and open the ball ; an idea that had never occurred to her before .

text: Whenever she had thought of the minutiae of the evening , it had been as a matter of course that Edmund would begin with Miss Crawford ; and the impression was so strong , that though _ her _ _ uncle _ spoke the contrary , she could not help an exclamation of surprise , a hint of her unfitness , an entreaty even to be excused .
text_tokenized: Whenever she had thought of the minutiae of the evening , it had been as a matter of course that Edmund would begin with Miss Crawford ; and the impression was so strong , that though _ her _ _ uncle _ spoke the contrary , she could not help an exclamation of surprise , a hint of her unfitness , an entreaty even to be excused .

text: To be urging her opinion against Sir Thomas ’s was a proof of the extremity of the case ; but such was her horror at the first suggestion , that she could actually look him in the face and say that she hoped it might be settled otherwise
text_tokenized: To be urging her opinion against Sir Thomas ’s was a proof of the extremity of the case ; but such was her horror at the first suggestion , that she could actually look him in the face and say that she hoped it might be settled otherwise

text: ; in vain , however : Sir Thomas smiled , tried to encourage her , and then looked too serious , and said too decidedly , “ It must be so , my dear , ” for her to hazard another word ; and she found herself the next moment conducted by Mr. Crawford to the top of the room , and standing there to be joined by the rest of the dancers , couple after couple , as they were formed . She could hardly believe it .
text_tokenized: ; in vain , however : Sir Thomas smiled , tried to encourage her , and then looked too serious , and said too decidedly , “ It must be so , my dear , ” for her to hazard another word ; and she found herself the next moment conducted by Mr. Crawford to the top of the room , and standing there to be joined by the rest of the dancers , couple after couple , as they were formed . She could hardly believe it .

text: To be placed above so many elegant young women !
text_tokenized: To be placed above so many elegant young women !

text: The distinction was too great .
text_tokenized: The distinction was too great .

text: It was treating her like her cousins !
text_tokenized: It was treating her like her cousins !

text: And her thoughts flew to those absent cousins with most unfeigned and truly tender regret , that they were not at home to take their own place in the room , and have their share of a pleasure which would have been so very delightful to them . So often as she had heard them wish for a ball at home as the greatest of all felicities !
text_tokenized: And her thoughts flew to those absent cousins with most unfeigned and truly tender regret , that they were not at home to take their own place in the room , and have their share of a pleasure which would have been so very delightful to them . So often as she had heard them wish for a ball at home as the greatest of all felicities !

text: And to have them away when it was given — and for _ her _ to be opening the ball — and with Mr. Crawford too !
text_tokenized: And to have them away when it was given — and for _ her _ to be opening the ball — and with Mr. Crawford too !

text: She hoped they would not envy her that distinction _ now _ ; but when she looked back to the state of things in the autumn , to what they had all been to each other when once dancing in that house before
text_tokenized: She hoped they would not envy her that distinction _ now _ ; but when she looked back to the state of things in the autumn , to what they had all been to each other when once dancing in that house before

text: , the present arrangement was almost more than she could understand herself . The ball began .
text_tokenized: , the present arrangement was almost more than she could understand herself . The ball began .

text: It was rather honour than happiness to Fanny , for the first dance at least : her partner was in excellent spirits , and tried to impart them to her ; but she was a great deal too much frightened to have any enjoyment till she could suppose herself no longer looked at .
text_tokenized: It was rather honour than happiness to Fanny , for the first dance at least : her partner was in excellent spirits , and tried to impart them to her ; but she was a great deal too much frightened to have any enjoyment till she could suppose herself no longer looked at .

text: Young , pretty , and gentle , however , she had no awkwardnesses that were not as good as graces , and there were few persons present that were not disposed to praise her .
text_tokenized: Young , pretty , and gentle , however , she had no awkwardnesses that were not as good as graces , and there were few persons present that were not disposed to praise her .

text: She was attractive , she was modest , she was Sir Thomas ’s niece , and she was soon said to be admired by Mr. Crawford .
text_tokenized: She was attractive , she was modest , she was Sir Thomas ’s niece , and she was soon said to be admired by Mr. Crawford .

text: It was enough to give her general favour .
text_tokenized: It was enough to give her general favour .

text: Sir Thomas himself was watching her progress down the dance with much complacency ; he was proud of his niece ; and without attributing all her personal beauty , as Mrs. Norris seemed to do , to her transplantation to Mansfield , he was pleased with himself for having supplied everything else : education and manners she owed to him . Miss Crawford saw much of Sir Thomas ’s thoughts as he stood , and having , in spite of all his wrongs towards her , a general prevailing desire of recommending herself to him , took an opportunity of stepping aside to say something agreeable of Fanny .
text_tokenized: Sir Thomas himself was watching her progress down the dance with much complacency ; he was proud of his niece ; and without attributing all her personal beauty , as Mrs. Norris seemed to do , to her transplantation to Mansfield , he was pleased with himself for having supplied everything else : education and manners she owed to him . Miss Crawford saw much of Sir Thomas ’s thoughts as he stood , and having , in spite of all his wrongs towards her , a general prevailing desire of recommending herself to him , took an opportunity of stepping aside to say something agreeable of Fanny .

text: Her praise was warm , and he received it as she could wish , joining in it as far as discretion , and politeness , and slowness of speech would allow , and certainly appearing
text_tokenized: Her praise was warm , and he received it as she could wish , joining in it as far as discretion , and politeness , and slowness of speech would allow , and certainly appearing

text: to greater advantage on the subject than his lady did soon afterwards , when Mary , perceiving her on a sofa very near , turned round before she began to dance , to compliment her on Miss Price ’s looks .
text_tokenized: to greater advantage on the subject than his lady did soon afterwards , when Mary , perceiving her on a sofa very near , turned round before she began to dance , to compliment her on Miss Price ’s looks .

text: “ Yes , she does look very well , ” was Lady Bertram ’s placid reply . “ Chapman helped her to dress .
text_tokenized: “ Yes , she does look very well , ” was Lady Bertram ’s placid reply . “ Chapman helped her to dress .

text: I sent Chapman to her . ”
text_tokenized: I sent Chapman to her . ”

text: Not but that she was really pleased to have Fanny admired ; but she was so much more struck with her own kindness in sending Chapman to her , that she could not get it out of her head .
text_tokenized: Not but that she was really pleased to have Fanny admired ; but she was so much more struck with her own kindness in sending Chapman to her , that she could not get it out of her head .

text: Miss Crawford knew Mrs. Norris too well to think of gratifying _ her _ by commendation of Fanny ; to her , it was as the occasion offered—“Ah ! ma’am , how much we want dear Mrs. Rushworth and Julia to - night ! ” and Mrs. Norris paid her with as many smiles and courteous words as she had time for , amid so much occupation as she found for herself in making up card - tables , giving hints to Sir Thomas , and trying to move all the chaperons to a better part of the room .
text_tokenized: Miss Crawford knew Mrs. Norris too well to think of gratifying _ her _ by commendation of Fanny ; to her , it was as the occasion offered—“Ah ! ma’am , how much we want dear Mrs. Rushworth and Julia to - night ! ” and Mrs. Norris paid her with as many smiles and courteous words as she had time for , amid so much occupation as she found for herself in making up card - tables , giving hints to Sir Thomas , and trying to move all the chaperons to a better part of the room .

text: Miss Crawford blundered most towards Fanny herself in her intentions to please .
text_tokenized: Miss Crawford blundered most towards Fanny herself in her intentions to please .

text: She meant to be giving her little heart a happy flutter , and filling her with sensations of delightful self - consequence ; and , misinterpreting Fanny ’s blushes , still thought she must be doing so when she went to her after the two first dances , and said , with a significant look , “ Perhaps _ you _ can tell me why my brother goes to town to - morrow ?
text_tokenized: She meant to be giving her little heart a happy flutter , and filling her with sensations of delightful self - consequence ; and , misinterpreting Fanny ’s blushes , still thought she must be doing so when she went to her after the two first dances , and said , with a significant look , “ Perhaps _ you _ can tell me why my brother goes to town to - morrow ?

text: He says he has business there , but will not tell me what .
text_tokenized: He says he has business there , but will not tell me what .

text: The first time he ever denied me his confidence !
text_tokenized: The first time he ever denied me his confidence !

text: But this is what we all come to .
text_tokenized: But this is what we all come to .

text: All are supplanted sooner or later .
text_tokenized: All are supplanted sooner or later .

text: Now , I must apply to you for information .
text_tokenized: Now , I must apply to you for information .

text: Pray , what is Henry going for ?
text_tokenized: Pray , what is Henry going for ?

text: Fanny protested her ignorance as steadily as her embarrassment allowed .
text_tokenized: Fanny protested her ignorance as steadily as her embarrassment allowed .

text: “ Well , then , ” replied Miss Crawford , laughing , “ I must suppose it to be purely for the pleasure of conveying your brother , and of talking of you by the way . ”
text_tokenized: “ Well , then , ” replied Miss Crawford , laughing , “ I must suppose it to be purely for the pleasure of conveying your brother , and of talking of you by the way . ”

text: Fanny was confused , but it was the confusion of discontent ;
text_tokenized: Fanny was confused , but it was the confusion of discontent ;

text: while Miss Crawford wondered she did not smile , and thought her over - anxious , or thought her odd , or thought her anything rather than insensible of
text_tokenized: while Miss Crawford wondered she did not smile , and thought her over - anxious , or thought her odd , or thought her anything rather than insensible of

text: pleasure in Henry ’s attentions
text_tokenized: pleasure in Henry ’s attentions

text: Fanny had a good deal of enjoyment in the course of the evening ; but Henry ’s attentions had very little to do with it .
text_tokenized: Fanny had a good deal of enjoyment in the course of the evening ; but Henry ’s attentions had very little to do with it .

text: She would much rather _ not _ have been asked by him again so very soon , and she wished she had not been obliged to suspect that his previous inquiries of Mrs. Norris , about the supper hour , were all for the sake of securing her at that part of the evening .
text_tokenized: She would much rather _ not _ have been asked by him again so very soon , and she wished she had not been obliged to suspect that his previous inquiries of Mrs. Norris , about the supper hour , were all for the sake of securing her at that part of the evening .

text: But it was not to be avoided : he made her feel that she was the object of all ; though she could not say that it was unpleasantly done , that there was indelicacy or ostentation in his manner ; and sometimes , when he talked of William , he was really not unagreeable , and shewed even a warmth of heart which did him credit .
text_tokenized: But it was not to be avoided : he made her feel that she was the object of all ; though she could not say that it was unpleasantly done , that there was indelicacy or ostentation in his manner ; and sometimes , when he talked of William , he was really not unagreeable , and shewed even a warmth of heart which did him credit .

text: But still his attentions made no part of her satisfaction .
text_tokenized: But still his attentions made no part of her satisfaction .

text: She was happy whenever she looked at William , and saw how perfectly he was enjoying himself , in every five minutes that she could walk about with him and hear his account of his partners ; she was happy in knowing herself admired ; and she was happy in having the two dances with Edmund still to look forward to , during the greatest part of the evening , her hand being so eagerly sought after that her indefinite engagement with _ him _ was in continual perspective .
text_tokenized: She was happy whenever she looked at William , and saw how perfectly he was enjoying himself , in every five minutes that she could walk about with him and hear his account of his partners ; she was happy in knowing herself admired ; and she was happy in having the two dances with Edmund still to look forward to , during the greatest part of the evening , her hand being so eagerly sought after that her indefinite engagement with _ him _ was in continual perspective .

text: She was happy even when they did take place ; but not from any flow of spirits on his side , or any such expressions of tender gallantry as had blessed the morning . His mind was fagged , and her happiness sprung from being the friend with whom it could find repose .
text_tokenized: She was happy even when they did take place ; but not from any flow of spirits on his side , or any such expressions of tender gallantry as had blessed the morning . His mind was fagged , and her happiness sprung from being the friend with whom it could find repose .

text: “ I am worn out with civility , ” said he .
text_tokenized: “ I am worn out with civility , ” said he .

text: “ I have been talking incessantly all night , and with nothing to say .
text_tokenized: “ I have been talking incessantly all night , and with nothing to say .

text: But with _ you _ , Fanny , there may be peace .
text_tokenized: But with _ you _ , Fanny , there may be peace .

text: You will not want to be talked to .
text_tokenized: You will not want to be talked to .

text: Let us have the luxury of silence . ”
text_tokenized: Let us have the luxury of silence . ”

text: Fanny would hardly even speak her agreement .
text_tokenized: Fanny would hardly even speak her agreement .

text: A weariness , arising probably , in great measure , from the same feelings which he had acknowledged in the morning , was peculiarly to be respected , and they went down their two dances together with such sober tranquillity as might satisfy any looker - on that Sir Thomas had been bringing up no wife for his younger son .
text_tokenized: A weariness , arising probably , in great measure , from the same feelings which he had acknowledged in the morning , was peculiarly to be respected , and they went down their two dances together with such sober tranquillity as might satisfy any looker - on that Sir Thomas had been bringing up no wife for his younger son .

text: The evening had afforded Edmund little pleasure .
text_tokenized: The evening had afforded Edmund little pleasure .

text: Miss Crawford had been in gay spirits when they first danced together , but it was not her gaiety that could do him good : it rather sank than raised his comfort ; and afterwards , for he found himself still impelled to seek her again , she had absolutely pained him by her manner of speaking of the profession to which he was now on the point of belonging .
text_tokenized: Miss Crawford had been in gay spirits when they first danced together , but it was not her gaiety that could do him good : it rather sank than raised his comfort ; and afterwards , for he found himself still impelled to seek her again , she had absolutely pained him by her manner of speaking of the profession to which he was now on the point of belonging .

text: They had talked , and they had been silent ; he had reasoned , she had ridiculed ; and they had parted at last with mutual vexation .
text_tokenized: They had talked , and they had been silent ; he had reasoned , she had ridiculed ; and they had parted at last with mutual vexation .

text: Fanny , not able to refrain entirely from observing them , had seen enough to be tolerably satisfied .
text_tokenized: Fanny , not able to refrain entirely from observing them , had seen enough to be tolerably satisfied .

text: It was barbarous to be happy when Edmund was suffering .
text_tokenized: It was barbarous to be happy when Edmund was suffering .

text: Yet some happiness must and would arise from the very conviction that he did suffer .
text_tokenized: Yet some happiness must and would arise from the very conviction that he did suffer .

text: When her two dances with him were over , her inclination and strength for more were pretty well at an end ; and Sir Thomas , having seen her walk rather than dance down the shortening set , breathless , and with her hand at her side , gave his orders for her sitting down entirely .
text_tokenized: When her two dances with him were over , her inclination and strength for more were pretty well at an end ; and Sir Thomas , having seen her walk rather than dance down the shortening set , breathless , and with her hand at her side , gave his orders for her sitting down entirely .

text: From that time Mr. Crawford sat down likewise .
text_tokenized: From that time Mr. Crawford sat down likewise .

text: “ Poor Fanny ! ” cried William , coming for a moment to visit her , and working away his partner ’s fan as if for life , “ how soon she is knocked up !
text_tokenized: “ Poor Fanny ! ” cried William , coming for a moment to visit her , and working away his partner ’s fan as if for life , “ how soon she is knocked up !

text: Why , the sport is but just begun .
text_tokenized: Why , the sport is but just begun .

text: I hope we shall keep it up these two hours .
text_tokenized: I hope we shall keep it up these two hours .

text: How can you be tired so soon ? ”
text_tokenized: How can you be tired so soon ? ”

text: “ So soon !
text_tokenized: “ So soon !

text: my good friend , ” said Sir Thomas , producing his watch with all necessary caution ; “ it is three o’clock , and your sister is not used to these sort of hours . ”

text: “ Advise ” was his word , but it was the advice of absolute power , and she had only to rise , and , with Mr. Crawford ’s very cordial adieus , pass quietly away ; stopping at the entrance - door , like the Lady of Branxholm Hall , “ one moment and no more , ” to view the happy scene , and take a last look at the five or six determined couple who were still hard at work ; and then , creeping slowly up the principal staircase , pursued by the ceaseless country - dance , feverish with hopes and fears , soup and negus , sore - footed and fatigued , restless and agitated , yet feeling , in spite of everything , that a ball was indeed delightful . In thus sending her away , Sir Thomas perhaps might not be thinking

text: She could think of William the next day more cheerfully ; and as the morning afforded her an opportunity of talking over Thursday night with Mrs. Grant and Miss Crawford , in a very handsome style , with all the heightenings of imagination , and all the laughs of playfulness which are so essential to the shade of a departed ball , she could afterwards bring her mind without much effort into its everyday state , and easily conform to the tranquillity of the present quiet week . They were indeed a smaller party than she had ever known there for a whole day together , and _ he _ was gone on whom the comfort and cheerfulness of every family meeting and every meal chiefly depended .

text: “ That is the first question , you know , ” said Miss Crawford , trying to appear gay and unconcerned , “ which every woman who plays herself is sure to ask about another .
text_tokenized: “ That is the first question , you know , ” said Miss Crawford , trying to appear gay and unconcerned , “ which every woman who plays herself is sure to ask about another .

text: But it is very foolish to ask questions about any young ladies — about any three sisters just grown up ; for one knows , without being told , exactly what they are : all very accomplished and pleasing , and one very pretty .
text_tokenized: But it is very foolish to ask questions about any young ladies — about any three sisters just grown up ; for one knows , without being told , exactly what they are : all very accomplished and pleasing , and one very pretty .

text: Indeed , how can one care for those one has never seen ?

text: Well , when your cousin comes back , he will find Mansfield very quiet ; all the noisy ones gone , your brother and mine and myself .
